Idiom (Interglossa): Da sona plu via es na sofi.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause with comparative particle 'plu' (more) and copular verb 'es'.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Said when someone acts without wisdom despite having experience — similar to 'older but not wiser.'
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Experience does not always mean wisdom.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from postcolonial proverb culture in the Southern Interglossa islands emphasizing humility.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Interglossa: /da ˈsona plu ˈvia es na ˈsofi/
First Example Sentence: Da sona plu via es na sofi, e mi amika poka risu.
Second Example Sentence: Ufa, tu pensa tu sapi, ma da sona plu via es na sofi!
Third Example Sentence: Mi patri sempri dice: da sona plu via es na sofi.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed subject-predicate clause with possessive pronoun 'su'.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Used when someone is caught red-handed or exposed.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: They have been caught in the act.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Originates from coastal trade jargon where 'feno' (hand) symbolized manual labor and 'teo' (tea) meant being observed or judged.
First Example Sentence: Ha! Li feno es su teo, tu non pote nega.
Second Example Sentence: Na vidi an face, li feno es su teo.
Third Example Sentence: Mi dice: li feno es su teo, fini historia.

Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Past tense verb 'pa trinka' with reflexive-like possessive 'su voce'.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Said of someone who lost inspiration or confidence to speak.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: They lost their voice or courage to express themselves.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: From an old poetic metaphor of the 'muse' drinking the poet’s words when inspiration fades.
First Example Sentence: Post la disputa, mi senti ke musa pa trinka su voce.
Second Example Sentence: Li poeta dice ke musa pa trinka su voce per silentio.
Third Example Sentence: Musa pa trinka su voce, e la scena resti morta.

Idiom (Interglossa): Mi luna non luce tota nocte.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Negative clause with temporal adverbial phrase.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Used to admit one’s imperfection or temporary weakness.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: I’m not perfect all the time.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Draws from agrarian belief in lunar influence, reflecting humility and cyclic imperfection.
First Example Sentence: Mi luna non luce tota nocte, so mi fa error.
Second Example Sentence: Non juzga mi dura — mi luna non luce tota nocte.
Third Example Sentence: Mi luna non luce tota nocte, ma mi prova cado-dex.

Idiom (Interglossa): La venti porta plu rumor ke nova.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Comparative structure with plural noun and prepositional phrase.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Refers to exaggerated or false gossip spreading quickly.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Stems from maritime proverb traditions comparing wind and rumor’s reach.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Interglossa: /la ˈventi ˈporta plu ˈrumor ke ˈnova/
First Example Sentence: La venti porta plu rumor ke nova in tota vila.
Second Example Sentence: Non kreda tuto — la venti porta plu rumor ke nova.
Third Example Sentence: La venti porta plu rumor ke nova, ma silenti dura plu longa.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Used to advise against building something on unstable foundations.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common saying from coastal agricultural communities emphasizing planning and foresight.
First Example Sentence: Pe sabla non planta arbo, dice anci mi matra.
Second Example Sentence: Tu proekta es bela, ma pe sabla non planta arbo.
Third Example Sentence: Pe sabla non planta arbo — pensa ante age.

Idiom (Interglossa): U li aqua kanta, li peixi fuji.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Conditional clause with coordinated verb phrase.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Said when someone reveals too much and causes trouble.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Drawn from river-trade communities — water that ‘sings’ scares fish, symbolizing indiscretion.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Interglossa: /u li ˈakwa ˈkanta, li ˈpeɪʃi ˈfuji/
First Example Sentence: U li aqua kanta, li peixi fuji — parla tro e perde tot.
Second Example Sentence: Mi memori li senyo: u li aqua kanta, li peixi fuji.
Third Example Sentence: U li aqua kanta, li peixi fuji — silenti es oro.

Idiom (Interglossa): Li cora es plu longa ke li lingua.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Used to mean feelings run deeper than words.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: The heart feels more than the tongue can say.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Popularized by Interglossa romantic poetry in the late 19th century.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Interglossa: /li ˈkora es plu ˈlɔŋga ke li ˈliŋgwa/
First Example Sentence: Li cora es plu longa ke li lingua, dice poeta Amoni.
Second Example Sentence: Mi senti tro, parla poko — li cora es plu longa ke li lingua.
Third Example Sentence: Li cora es plu longa ke li lingua, e li oki parla separe.

Idiom (Interglossa): Mi pani pa rosti ante festa.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Past tense with temporal adverbial phrase.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Means someone celebrated or assumed success too early.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Don’t count your chickens before they hatch.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Originates from communal feast traditions where early roasting symbolized impatience.
First Example Sentence: Mi pani pa rosti ante festa — e la kontrakta non veni.
Second Example Sentence: Tu ja pa rosti tu pani ante festa, fratri.
Third Example Sentence: Mi pani pa rosti ante festa, ma mi apreende lecion.

Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Not everything that looks good is valuable.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Introduced during early standardization of Interglossa proverbs for education in the 1950s.
First Example Sentence: Non tota oro brili, memori tu.
Second Example Sentence: Mi matra dice: non tota oro brili.
Third Example Sentence: Non tota oro brili — veri parola de sapiensa.
